Many cats like to be scratched on and around their heads (only.)  Some cats 
will let people rub their bellies, some hate it.  I have one cat that gets 
upset if you get near her feet with your hand (she hates being touched 
there.)  Not too unlike humans -- a lot of us have ticklish or sensitive 
areas.  Just watch your cat's tail, ears and movements to watch out for 
irritation.  If you learn that your cat doesn't like to be scratched or 
rubbed somewhere, just avoid that area.  He'd do the same for you!

comments.text:
I wrote a response to your comment just now.  I don't know where it will 
appear, but I'm saying that it's a wide world and there's so much to know, 
so much to learn. If your family didn't teach you about how to pat a cat, 
or you never had a cat, it is not automatic to be able to pick up on what a 
cat feels.  There are also many things that interfere with people's 
sensitivity or ability to detect people's or cats' feelings.  Constant 
scolding as a child will do it. Trauma (your house burns down) can do it.  
Jackson Galaxy is gentle and non-judgmental when he teaches us about cats.  
But it seems to me that he studied cats and he read about cats—he didn't 
just start out knowing all this.  So don't be shocked at people not 
knowing, and put them down. I think it does make us feel better when we do 
this, but it's a trap—that I've been working on for years!
comments.author: Wendalore65

+Rachelle R We have only two rules for animals in our home. 1) Don't chew 
on us. 2) Don't chew on anything important to us Ie. paperwork. Our animals 
do great learning these rules, they may (as children) chew on furniture, 
but destroy no more than a human toddler would with juice or food. They DO 
learn what you teach them, and many animals are wiser than humans. My 
husky/malamute for instance, tells me every time she's lonely, hungry, 
needs to go out, for a walk, wants to play, thirsty, or tired. She 
distinguishes her actions from the next, but she does it in a different way 
than a human would. Thus why some humans don't pick up on these actions. 
You have to learn how to speak animal to interact with them. We're mammals 
too, we should have already known this.

comments.text:
One big problem here - cats, dogs, birds, humans - are not all the 
same. they can be born with physical/chemical/neurological problems that 
"tough love" is not the answer to. It sounds to me like your pets are happy 
and healthy, glad to hear it. In my home, I work hard for our food and 
shelter and in sharing that, it is appropriate that my pets have 
guidelines, boundaries, and respect for me - that is healthy for all 
intelligent beings. However, I keep in mind that behavior problems 
sometimes point to medical conditions that can be causing pain, or chemical 
imbalances that cause distress. It is a good idea to consider this 
possibility, and use intelligence, patience and compassion. Many pets with 
touch problems aren't being "bad", it's their only way to communicate pain 
or distress. Some people don't have the patience for that, but my belief 
is, human or animal, they didn't ask to be born that way/become that way, 
and deserve a little understanding.  I wonder what you would have done with 
Lux cat... I'm not sure a week in the woods would have helped him. that 
being said, it is admirable you give a home to so many critters. I respect 
your rules for your home - but admittedly, no respect for criticizing 
"y'all" for not doing things your way and your way only.
comments.author: Rachelle R

comments.text:
maybe you are using the toy wrong.  I know it sounds crazy but hear me out. 
 Just crashing it into him and "wrestling" him with it isn't going to do it 
for him.  Cats are ambush predators.  They spend a long time sneaking up on 
victims, planning out their attack, or even just hiding and waiting for one 
to come close enough.  It is more about the sneaking up on prey and 
watching it, and the pouncing part is the minor portion.  Put the toy 
behind a wall or the couch where he can only see a little glimpse of it 
every now and then, and let him sneak up on it.  Be VERY subtle and slow.
Get one of those feather toys on the stick.  They are great.  You have to 
mimic a wounded bird, or maybe a foraging mouse with it.
Last, cats just stop playing so much when they get to a certain age. 
 That's just how they are.  They lose their prey drive and just want to 
focus on cuddles and they shift to you for their daily stimulation instead 
of play and exploration.
comments.author: Tom Long

comments.text:
+Caitlin Veal Well, training would be involved, and lots of it.  I have 
trained my girls from the moment they adopted me.  I have one that follows 
me from room to room, that just needs to be in the same room as me, but I 
have another one that insists on getting in the way when I'm in a hurry. 
 There were two solutions for the one that gets in my way.  The first one 
was to pick her up and carry her with me, placing her down out of the way 
when I get to where I need to go.  That didn't work, because she would 
scoot quickly out of reach after she realised what I was doing.  Since she 
was approx. 1.5 years when I got her from the rescue, I couldn't train her 
from her kittenhood, and she can be a bit skittish with sudden movements, 
so when in a hurry and she gets in the way, I'll stop and mimic running on 
the spot, which sends her scurrying ahead.  She also demands LOTS of 
attention, when my older girl is out of the room (Older girl chases her 
away, she is VERY possessive of me in our room).  So the younger one is 
insistent that I pay her attention as much as possible.  She is a VERY 
loving girl.  When she becomes annoying with her bugging for attention, 
I'll give her attention for a good 20 minutes or so, but then I'll gently 
but firmly place her next to me on the couch.  If she gets up for more 
attention, I repeatedly gently but firmly place her next to me on the 
couch.  If it continues, then I gently, but firmly hold her there.  When 
she began to learn to stay, I would pet her as a reward, and show her that 
she will ONLY get pet when she behaves.  I also talk a LOT to my girls. 
 They LOVE being talked to, because it's still giving them attention.  They 
do eventually learn to understand simple things, like 'No', 'Stay', 'Good 
Girl/Boy!', 'I Love You!' and be sure to let your boy see your expressions 
as you teach him these words.  It takes great training and greater 
patience.  Also, whenever he chirps at you, reply to him.  My older girl 
talks to me ALL THE TIME, and I reply every time, even if it's 'Yes?'.  She 
even has certain calls for certain things, and I've learned to understand 
what she's asking of me with the tone she takes.  They learn to understand 
a LOT.  I hope this helps.

comments.text:
Actually, cats need to be socialized when they are young, but those cats 
might get more used to you over time - especially since you feed them and 
they trust you enough to enter your house. But what is really important 
right now is that you get ALL of the cats fixed immediately. Female cats 
can get pregnant when they are six months old. And you should also get them 
vaccinated when you take them to the vet. Be sure to always use a cat 
carrier when you are transporting a cat because they may jump out of your 
arms if they get frightened. If you can't catch the two semi-tame cats, you 
will need to borrow cat traps from your county pound. You will then need to 
take them to get spayed or neutered and then board them at the vet's office 
until the vet can take the stitches out. Release them in your house near 
some food. But PLEASE DON'T dump them at the pound where they will be 
murdered. And PLEASE DON'T dump them somewhere else where they will starve. 
For more information, look up Alley Cat Allies on the Internet and contact 
them if you need to. Also, if cost is an issue, look into low-cost 
spay/neuter programs in your area. Thank you for being a kind person and 
feeding those cats.

comments.text:
It depends on the cat - I've known a lot of them (including indoor cats 
who'd been around humans all their lives) that would bite or scratch if you 
petted them too roughly. The way he explains it is a bit new-agey, but I do 
think it's an overstimulation thing. There might be something genetic going 
on - the cats I have now are littermates, and they rarely get 
overstimulated and love being petted roughly. However, one of them will 
still push my hand away when he's had too much. The cats I grew up with 
would get overstimulated - if you did something like scratch them roughly, 
they'd love it, until they suddenly decided they were done and would bite 
and scratch. Most of them did it gently as a warning, but one of them would 
break the skin, so I made a point not to over-pet him.

Our cat Ruby nursed on herself for almost a year (especially when she was 
sleepy.)  She eventually outgrew it.  Some cats do it for a long time. 
 It's not uncommon (think of it as a child not ready to give up the 
pacifier.)  You can buy special pillows with nipples built in for the cat 
to nurse on, but we just regularly checked the area to make sure it wasn't 
becoming raw or infected.  Try a snuggle when your cat starts trying to 
nurse.  She's probably just wanting comfort.

comments.text:
This is a behaviour that comes from being separated too early from the cats 
mother. My first cat was just 7 weeks when given to me and the first night 
I woke up to him kneadkng and trying to suckle on MY boob! I moved him away 
from my boob. Soon I woke up again, this time he was sucking my earlobe! 
Again, gently removed him. An hour later I wake up to him kneading my 
scalp, licking, sucking and drooling on my ponytail. At that point I 
thought "fine, cuddle with my hair". He then did this every night for his 
entire life. My second cats mom got run over by a car when he was 9 weeks 
so even though I got him a month later, same issue, sepapated too soon. 
He's 12 y.o now, still tries to suck on owners' earlobes daily.
Cats should be at least 12w before taken from their mom but all cats are 
different and some need to be more/less than 12 weeks. 
Have seen cats suckle on dogs, owners shirts, ears, hair, blankets etc. 
Sometimes it becomes a life long behaviour but is rarely dangerous. Also, 
nipples are meant to be suckled, I think it would take a lot for your cat 
to actually damaging him-/herself that way.

comments.text:
I am no expert on cats, but I do know a thing or two about them. I like to 
think a cat who has never been outside might not have any wish to do so. 
But if he does, him getting lost is the least of your worries. Like dogs, 
cats can always find their way back home. The bigger concern are all the 
hazards he can run into outside such as mean dogs and other aggressive 
animals, diseases carried by fleas and ticks, and moving vehicles. However, 
cats are usually good at staying out of trouble. And so long as the cat has 
had all his shots, including rabies, and is given a good flea and tick 
preventative, he may do just fine outside. I myself always let my cats go 
outside when they wish and they always come home later. Also, a GPS collar 
isn't a bad idea, so long as you don't think it may get snagged and lost 
somewhere while the cat is out exploring.
comments.author: Neila Whoon

we dewormed her through a local vet and he had us give her medicine bought 
from the local grange since he just didn't have time to write a 
prescription, The day after we gave this to her it resulted in : attacks on 
the dogs she'd known her entire life, attacks on humans, walls, bedding, 
biting over her favorite foods, and peeing in the house (which she'd never 
done before). She fell ill on a friday night, she moped, wouldn't eat or 
drink, and got lethargic, the vet wasn't open until monday morning, Sadly 
by monday morning we took her in and the vet had old us she was too 
dehydrated and her organs were too affected by it in 2 days to save her, 
and we had to say goodbye. Please triple check the labels and ask questions 
about prescriptions for pets even if veterinarian recommended. :/

comments.text:
+francesca palmer Cats DO eat grass! It helps them bring up bones etc, if 
they are out hunting, and fur-balls, if he's an indoor cat. You can get 
specific cat grass from pet shops. If he goes outside, you just need to 
keep an eye on whether the grass might have been treated at all, as that 
could cause problems. If he's stopped eating grass, (along with the food 
being part digested, rather than regurgitated!) that could indicate a 
furball blockage that's built up.  Here's some more info about grass and 
cats. http://www.knowyourcat.info/info/catingrass.htm  

If he's still vomiting after having some grass, or specially developed 
furball remedy, I'd suggest going back to your vet as they SHOULD be able 
to feel if there are any major blockages. If they cannot, it may be a good 
idea to have an ultrasound. I had a cat (a Siamese called Delilah) who was 
vomiting part digested food for many months. I eventually saw another vet 
at the same practice and they could feel a blockage straight away. She had 
ultrasound and there was actually a tumour, that they successfully removed. 
She was fine afterwards, but I was angry that I had been to them so many 
times, knowing in my heart that there was more to it than this one vet 
thought. But she was my first cat and I thought vets were infallible, and 
that it must be something minor and I was paranoid. I hate to think how 
much she was suffering from pain before the truth was found. It's always 
good to get other opinions, as you have had. But as the problem has 
persisted without resolution, it's better to get it checked again, if the 
grass and hairball remedy don't resolve the situation. NOT by the vet that 
thought him being sick was due to him smelling other cats you've had 
before, though! That is the weirdest thing I've ever heard. Scent-marking 
in those areas I can understand. But, vomiting? Bizarre! Hope you get somme 
answers soon. H x
comments.author: Mad Cat Lady 72

comments.text:
its slightly lumpy and bubbley it used to have grass in it, but now i make

comments.author: francesca palmer

comments.text:
+francesca palmer Nobody really likes sick. Most of all, your cat. You 
don't need to study it for longer than a couple of seconds. Which you would 
be doing as you clean it up anyway! It should be very obvious what the 
consistency is, unless you are doing that blindfolded! It's either slightly 
puffed up biscuits (where they've soaked up some liquid!) or more of a 
smooth consistency. I would have thought the 3 vets you went to would have 
asked about the form the 'puke' comes in. The first type indicates 
regurgitating, probably due to having too much food available. The second 
implies that, as the food is part digested, this happens further down in 
the digestion process. That may be due to a blockage of some sort. Maybe 
fur balls or something similar. I would also suggest you look at how much 
water you have down for him, particularly as you seem to keep his bowls 
topped up. Generally, for every part of dry food, they require 4 times that 
volume of water. You could try the bottled water, or a water fountain with 
a filter. The fountain would be better to ensure he's drinking enough 
oxygenated water, which a bowl is not. Also water, if not using a fountain, 
shouldn't be served in a plastic bowl as the plastic makes it taste 
unpleasant. A glass, stainless steel, or ceramic bowl is much better, and 
he'll therefore probably drink much more.
comments.author: Mad Cat Lady 72

top_comment.text:
For the record, there is 1 kind of cat that will not bit you. Loves to be 
held and stroked. Will let you carry them and hold them like a child, and 
it's not a breed, it's a medical condition called Cerebellar Hypoplasia or 
CHat/CHittens. These animals are born with a less developed cerebellum 
which is basically brain damage. It's usually difficult to adopt them due 
to people being put off on taking home a 'damaged' kitty. I myself did not 
want one. My wife picked one at the animal shelter and I was like no no no 
no no no not that cat, any cat but him. Not the brain damage part, the 
pacing and meowing, a total handful. Then I found out he had CH and I was 
like "Baby, the guy says he's brain damaged" my wife didn't care. My wife 
is awesome. I relented. We adopted. I named him Corky and he is one of the 
best cats I've ever been with. He could not walk very well when we got him 
and didn't move in a normal way, he would whip his head around constantly 
like Stevie Wonder playing on the drums, and he couldn't jump, was always 
tripping over himself, and basically lacks all of the inbred grace and 
beauty of feline kind. He is a perpetually drunk kitty. But as he developed 
and grew from a kitten into a cat, his coordination improved to the point 
that most people don't realize he's special. He can jump on the cat tree, 
he can run, and the stiffness in his gait is almost un-noticeable if you 
don't know what to look for. This cat.....You can sit him in the bath with 
you and bath him in a BATH and he just snuggles up like it's the best. You 
can trim his nails and he doesn't care. He doesn't jump on the kitchen 
counter, he doesn't try to eat whats on your plate. He's playful but not 
aggressive. He loves to be picked up and handled, and he never presents the 
belly only to claw you when you touch it. He's like pudding, you ladle him 
out of whatever container he's in and he flows into your arms like a bowl 
of jello you scooped out and he will just lay in whatever position you put 
him in, and just love everything you do together. They love to be stroked 
and held and they are just the greatest lap cats.﻿

captions.text:
We are here to talk about
why your cat beats you up.
Now, let's go get catified.

Today, we are in the land
of the supermarket question.

The supermarket question
is, Jackson, I got this cat,
he's really, really cool.

And every time we're sitting
together, out of the blue,
randomly he attacks me.

Of course, its never
out of the blue.

It's always because
of something.

And secondly, yes, you may have
bites and scratches on you,
but is that an attack?

Most times, when
folks are sitting here

just like me and him,
we're just sitting around,

we're not doing much of
anything-- good PC, good PC,
oh I love PC.
Look at this, look at this.
Bye, PC.
See you, PC.
Right?
And gone.
Why is that?

Petting-induced
overstimulation aggression.

And what happens there
is that certain cats--

and this is physiological,
this is not a matter

of temperament-- cannot take
being pet like this over
and over the over again.

It actually fills them
with a sort of static,

like a balloon, filled,
filled, and then bang.

You don't realize when
you're sitting watching TV

with your cat how
you're petting them.
So what is the cure for this?

All right, let's
look at number one.
Be observant.

Know when your cat
is getting worked up.

As you're petting, you're
going to notice the tail start
to twitch just a little.

And then that graduates, and
then starts going like this.

And then, you are
going to get bit.

Then there is what I
call back electricity.
Right down the back.

It's a cat going eew, ughh
In terms of stimulation,

they're just getting
to that point.

It's up to you to
notice these things.

And if you notice
that, the aggression
is not going to happen.

Know where your cat enjoys
